questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought by his parents because he has been skipping school to work feverishly on a project he says will save the world. He has decreased sleep, increased energy, disordered thoughts, and excessive talking. He has thoughts that he has a lot of money and is the leader of the ‘international children's liberation army’. What is the most probable diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Maniac episode of Bipolar mood disorder

questions.correct_answer: A. Maniac episode of Bipolar mood disorder
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maniac episode of Bipolar mood disorder The patient presents with grandiosity, inflated self-esteem, paranoia, a decreased need for sleep, an increased energy level, and pressured speech , which all are suggestive of Mania.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: B. ADHD which is characterized by distractibility, impulsivity, and hyperactivity that is present daily Option: C. Schizophrenia is characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, and negative symptoms. In this patient grandiosity and increased self-esteem is at the ideas level, not at the delusion level as they are shakable and not fixed. Option: D. Conduct disorder is where the person definitely breaks major social rules , destroys the property of others, and tortures animals.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female is brought to the hospital by her sister with complaints of increased talking, change in behavior, use of unnecessary words and sentences while talking, and reduced sleep since 2 weeks. She says that before 2 weeks her sister would just sit crying in her room, not eating or sleeping well, and wouldn’t do much work. False about this patient is-

options.label: A
options.text: The disorder most often starts with depression and is recurring.

options.label: B
options.text: The manic episodes have a delayed onset and evolve over months

options.label: C
options.text: They have a poor prognosis compared to major depressive disorder

questions.correct_answer: B. The manic episodes have a delayed onset and evolve over months
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The manic episodes have a delayed onset and evolve over months The given case history points towards bipolar mood disorder . The manic episodes typically have a rapid onset (hours or days) but may evolve over a few weeks. An untreated manic episode lasts about 3 months ; therefore, clinicians should not discontinue giving drugs before that time.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Bipolar I disorder most often starts with depression (75 percent of the time in women, 67 percent in men) and is recurring. Most patients experience both depressive and manic episodes, although 10 to 20 percent experience only manic episodes. Option: C. Patients with bipolar I disorder have a poorer prognosis than patients with major depressive disorder

questions.text: The true statement about psychodynamic factors in the mood disorder is shown below: Disturbances during the oral phase predispose to depression Loss of an object is regarded with love and hate and feelings of anger towards self develops Mania episodes are a defense mechanism against underlying depression Depression can be linked to real or imagined object loss. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above The image shows bipolar disorder with depression, mania, and mixed episodes . Most theories of mania view manic episodes as a defense against underlying depression.

questions.text: Identify the following mood disorders correctly:

options.label: A
options.text: 1= Bipolar I, 2= Bipolar II, 3= cyclothymia, 4= Depression

options.label: B
options.text: 1= Bipolar I, 2= Bipolar II, 3= Depression, 4= cyclothymia

options.label: C
options.text: 1= Bipolar I, 2= cyclothymia, 3= Bipolar II, 4 = Depression

questions.correct_answer: C. 1= Bipolar I, 2= cyclothymia, 3= Bipolar II, 4 = Depression
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1= Bipolar I, 2= cyclothymia, 3= Bipolar II, 4 = Depression Therefore, other options are not correct.

Extraedge:

Depression - A major depressive episode must last at least 2 weeks with changes in appetite and weight, changes in sleep and activity, lack of energy, feelings of guilt, problems thinking and making decisions, and recurring thoughts of death or suicide. Mania - A manic episode is a distinct period of an abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive, or irritable mood lasting for at least 1 week . A hypomanic episode lasts at least 4 days and is similar to a manic episode except that it is not sufficiently severe to cause impairment in social or occupational functioning, and no psychotic features are present. Bipolar I disorder is defined as having a clinical course of one or more manic episodes and, sometimes, major depressive disorder . A mixed episode is at least 1 week in which both a manic episode and a major depressive episode occur almost daily. Dysthymic disorder is characterized by at least 2 years of depressed mood t hat is not sufficiently severe to the diagnosis of a major depressive episode. Cyclothymic disorder is characterized by at least 2 years of frequently occurring hypomanic symptoms that cannot t the diagnosis of a manic episode and of depressive symptoms that cannot fit the diagnosis of a major depressive episode.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female is brought by her sister with complaints of reduced sleep, irrelevant talking and episodes of spending excessively, attended her uncle’s funeral in a happy mood, and was well dressed with fine makeup and heavy jewelry. The true statements about the treatment of this condition are:- It is the easiest phase to treat Severe cases should be admitted for aggressive dosing Combination therapy may be used in some patients The adherence to treatment is less due to a lack of insight Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All the above The given case is that of a patient with a bipolar mood disorder in acute mania .

Highyeild:

TREATMENT OF ACUTE MANIA. The treatment of acute mania, or hypomania, usually is the easiest phase of bipolar disorders to treat. Agents can be used alone or in combination to bring the patient down from a high. Patients with severe mania are best treated in the hospital where aggressive dosing is possible and an adequate response can be achieved within days or weeks. Treatment adherence , however, is often a problem because patients with mania frequently lack insight into their illness and refuse to take medication. Because impaired judgment, impulsivity, and aggressiveness combine to put the patient or others at risk, many patients in the manic phase are medicated to protect themselves and others from harm.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient with a mood disorder as depicted below comes for follow-up. The false statements regarding the management of this patient are:- Primary goal of treatment is to maintain euthymia Patients treated with lithium may develop hyperthyroidism Cognitive impairment can be a side-effect of treatment Lamotrigine has prophylactic antidepressant and mood-stabilizing properties Rate of the switch to mania in patients with lamotrigine is lesser than in patients on a placebo Select the Incorrect answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2 and 5 The image depicts bipolar mood disorder with several episodes of mania and depression . Points 2 and 5 are false statements. Point 1) Not only must the chosen regimen achieve its primary goal-sustained euthymia -but the medications should not produce unwanted side effects that affect functioning. Point 2) Thyroid supplementation is frequently necessary during the long-term Many patients treated with lithium develop hypothyroidism. Point 3) Sedation, cognitive impairment, tremor, weight gain, and rash are some side effects that lead to treatment discontinuation. Point 4) Lamotrigine has prophylactic antidepressant and, potentially, mood-stabilizing properties. Point 5) Patients with bipolar I disorder depression taking lamotrigine exhibit a rate of switch into a mania that is the same as the rate with placebo. Therefore, other options are not correct.

questions.text: A 24-year-old student with a history of bipolar disorder presents to the psychiatrist. He is dressed in a new white suit and is wearing a hat. He goes around the waiting room flirting with female patients, laughing, and talking loudly. Which of the following delusions is most consistent with his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: “I know that my family is going bankrupt; we won’t have anything to eat.”

options.label: B
options.text: “I heard them talking about me on TV, they clearly said my name.”

options.label: C
options.text: “My brain is melting inside. I know it.”

options.label: D
options.text: “NASA called me to be the director of their new space program.”

questions.correct_answer: D. “NASA called me to be the director of their new space program.”
questions.explanation:
Solution:

“NASA called me to be the director of their new space program.” The patient is presenting with a full-blown mania , in which delusions of grandeur are common and congruent with a euphoric and elated mood .

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Delusions of poverty are false beliefs that one is bereft or will be deprived of all material possessions which are frequently seen in depressive disorder. Option: B . Delusions of reference are false beliefs that one is being talked about by others. Option: C . Somatic delusion is a false belief involving the function of one’s body and can be seen in psychotic disorders of the schizophrenic spectrum, as well as in depressive disorders with psychotic features .

questions.text: A 30-year-old man suffered from eight episodes of mood disturbances within a single year. These mood episodes met the diagnostic criteria for major depression, mania, and hypomania. These episodes were separated by remission. Which of the following is the MOST likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rapid cycling bipolar disorder This patient has more than 4 episodes of mania and depressive disorder in 1 year fulfilling the criteria for rapid cycling bipolar disorder.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A . The patient having more than 4 episodes of mania and depressive disorder in 1 year, is too severe for cyclothymic disorder. Option: B . Dysthymic disorder is characterized by at least 2 years of depressed mood that is not sufficiently severe to the diagnosis of a major depressive episode. Option: C . Patients with schizoaffective disorder display both mood and psychotic symptoms simultaneously, either of which doesn’t qualify for an individual diagnosis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room by the police after she was found standing in the middle of a busy highway, naked, commanding the traffic to stop. In the emergency room, she is agitated and restless, with pressured speech and an effect that alternates between euphoric and irritable. Her father is contacted and states that this kind of behavior runs in the family. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bipolar disorder, manic Mood elevation , mood lability, irritability, expansive behavior, increased energy, decreased need for sleep, lack of insight, poor judgment, disinhibition, impulsivity , and pressured speech are characteristic symptoms of elated acute mania.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Delirium is characterized by an acute disturbance in consciousness which is not seen in this patient. Option: C . Cyclothymic disorder is symptomatically a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by episodes of hypomania and mild depression. Option: D . Merriment, elation, and infectiousness of mood are much more common in manic episodes than in schizophrenia. Schizophrenia is characterized by delusions, hallucinations, disorganized behavior or speech, and negative symptoms.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man describes himself as “on top of the world” to strangers. He is considering running for president of India since he views himself as more intelligent, handsome, and charismatic than anyone he knows. He has engaged in sexual activity with 8 different women over the past 8 days. Which symptoms would be seen in such a person during this episode but not during a major depressive episode?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flight of ideas This patient has bipolar disorder . He is currently in a manic episode . Flight of ideas, a rapid jumping of thoughts through a series of tenuously related ideas is characteristic of mania but not depression.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Anhedonia is characteristic of depression but not mania. Option: B . Decreased sleep is characteristic of both depression and mania. Option: C . Distractibility can be an attribute of both mania and depression.

questions.text: A young man was brought to the outpatient clinic by his family members with a history of increased talk, increased alcohol consumption, sexual promiscuity, irritability, decreased sleep, and not feeling tired even after prolonged activity. These changes have been noticed over 2 weeks. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mania All the symptoms mentioned in the question are characteristic of mania. Mood elevation, mood lability, irritability, expansive behavior, increased energy, decreased need for sleep, lack of insight, poor judgment, disinhibition, impulsivity, and pressured speech are characteristic symptoms of elated acute mania.

Random:

Explanation for Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Nymphomania is an excessive and uncontrollable sexual desire in women. Option: B . Schizophrenia is a disorder of thought with characteristic symptoms of second and third-person hallucinations, delusions, and somatic passivity. Option: D . Agitated depression is a relatively severe type of clinical depression that combines the persistent sadness, pessimism, low energy, and low or "empty" mood of typical depression with agitated symptoms such as irritability, anxiety, restlessness, excessive talking, fidgeting, and/or angry outbursts.
